question: 1 (f)
statement_html:
Which of the following is essentially a form of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus?

i. The area under the graph of \(\displaystyle f(x)\) between \(\displaystyle x=a\) and \(\displaystyle x=b\) is given by \(\displaystyle \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx\)

ii. \(\displaystyle \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx =\lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}f(x_{k})\Delta x\)

iii. The derivative with respect to time of the position of a molecule is v. The net displacement of the molecule from \(\displaystyle t=0\) to \(\displaystyle t=T\) is given by \(\displaystyle \int_{0}^{T}v(t)\,dt\)

iv. \(\displaystyle \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx = f'(b) - f'(a)\)
statement_latex:
Which of the following is essentially a form of the Fundamental Theorem
of Calculus?

i. The area under the graph of $\displaystyle f(x)$ between
$\displaystyle x=a$ and $\displaystyle x=b$ is given by
$\displaystyle \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx$

ii.
$\displaystyle \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx =\lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}f(x_{k})\Delta x$

iii. The derivative with respect to time of the position of a molecule
is \emph{v}. The net displacement of the molecule from
$\displaystyle t=0$ to $\displaystyle t=T$ is given by
$\displaystyle \int_{0}^{T}v(t)\,dt$

iv. $\displaystyle \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx = f'(b) - f'(a)$
statement_raw:
Which of the following is essentially a form of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus?

i. The area under the graph of <math> \displaystyle f(x) </math> between <math> \displaystyle x=a </math> and <math> \displaystyle x=b </math> is given by <math> \displaystyle \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx </math>

ii. <math> \displaystyle \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx =\lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}f(x_{k})\Delta x</math>

iii. The derivative with respect to time of the position of a molecule is ''v''. The net displacement of the molecule from <math> \displaystyle t=0 </math> to <math> \displaystyle t=T </math> is given by <math> \displaystyle \int_{0}^{T}v(t)\,dt </math>

iv. <math> \displaystyle \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx = f'(b) - f'(a) </math>
